user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileOpen_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_FileOpen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *local_path, int32 flags, int32 access_mode)
{
    int                             os_perm;
    int                             os_mode;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Check for a valid access mode
    ** For creating a file, OS_READ_ONLY does not make sense
    */
    switch (access_mode)
    {
        case OS_WRITE_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_WRONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_RDONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_WRITE:
            os_perm = O_RDWR;
            break;
        default:
            return OS_ERROR;
    }

    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_CREAT;
    }
    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_TRUNC;
    }

    os_perm |= OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS;

    os_mode = S_IRUSR | S_IWUSR | S_IRGRP | S_IWGRP | S_IROTH | S_IWOTH;

    impl->fd = open(local_path, os_perm, os_mode);

    if (impl->fd < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("open(%s): %s\n", local_path, strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    /*
     * If the flags included O_NONBLOCK, then
     * enable the "select" call on this handle.
     */
    impl->selectable = ((os_perm & O_NONBLOCK) != 0);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileOpen_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Fragments not included (and thus not flagged) were assessed as not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13: - The function parameters are already const-qualified where appropriate (const OS_object_token_t *token and const char *local_path), so they do not require further investigation for missing const. - Local scalar variables (os_perm, os_mode) and switch/case logic do not involve pointers and are outside the scope of Rule 8.13. - Use of strerror() is a standard library call returning a (non-modifiable) string; only its use in the debug call is present and no pointer-to-modifiable data is retained. - Macro invocation of open() itself is fine with a const char * argument (local_path is const). The listed suspicious fragments are those that involve obtaining a pointer to a table element (macro + impl declaration/assignment) and subsequent writes through that pointer (assigning to impl->fd and impl->selectable), and the table/ macro definitions that determine whether the pointer types should have been const-qualified. These should be investigated to ensure that pointers point to const-qualified types whenever possible.
